results.title: Biography of an atomic vet
results.creator_credit: Richard Schmiechen, Television Laboratory, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and Nick Mazzuco
results.brief_description: A personal account of one man’s involvement in the above ground atomic tests that took place in the United States during the 1950’s. Nick Mazzucco recalls the growing awareness of the massive ignorance and indifference of the government in the acceptance of ‘safe radiation levels’.

results.title: Biochemistry and molecular structure
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the role of molecular structure in determining biological activity. Shows correlation of structure and biological activity of sulfanilamide with a vitamin essential to bacterial growth as one example, then considers the effect on human cell growth of compounds similar to some found in cell chromosomes. Time-lapse photography shows the effect of one such compound, 5-fluorouracil, on growth of cancer cells. No other credits available.

results.title: Binning street
results.creator_credit: Gillian Coote and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Changing Australia”.
Looks at the range of people, culture, attitudes, traditions and the history that dwells in Binning Street, Erskineville. The program investigates current family life in Australian society in the 1980’s and how it has changed.

results.title: Bingo, bridesmaids and braces
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Tristram Miall and Gillian Armstrong
results.brief_description: In this documentary the lives of three working class women are examined as they grow up from the “not so innocent” age of fourteen, to “it’s happening too fast” at eighteen, through to “well we survived”, at the ripe young age of 26. During these years we witness the women confronting the very real issues of teenage pregnancy, love versus sex, and career choices.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Film Australia, Tristram Miall and Gillian Armstrong

results.title: Bing bang boom
results.creator_credit: Joseph Koenig, ONF | NFB and Joan Henson
results.brief_description: A novel way of discovering music without instruments, in a Grade 7 classroom. Innovator and Toronto composer R. Murray Shafer is teacher for a day. His purpose is to show children that music is more than painfully learned notes and scales. He has the class listen to every sound around them and then harmonize and orchestrate what they hear - their voices, hands, feet - into a rhythmic musical pattern. The result is a hit, and a convincing illustration that children learn best when it’s from the inside out. Awards: American Film Festival; Sydney.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joseph Koenig, ONF | NFB and Joan Henson

results.title: Binary bit patterns
results.creator_credit: Michael Whitney, Information International and Motion Graphics and Pyramid Films
results.brief_description: This film puts a musical backing to a kaleidoscope of regular and abstract patterns based on geometric computer forms. Rapid movement of these ever-changing images is created with variations in colour and visual effect. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.
